results.title: Our trip to Sydney
results.creator_credit: Bryce O'Neill-Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bryce O’Neill-Baker tells of the time when he was asked if he wanted to go to Sydney for a short trip. The next day, he joined a bus with family members and others from his community to visit Sydney for the weekend. As well as the normal sightseeing, he also got to experience the NAIDOC festival and warmly shares the effect this time had on his family.

results.title: This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Six young Indigenous Australians look back and reflect on the things, events and people that have inspired, encouraged and, ultimately, shaped them into the youth leaders they have become. While telling different stories, they all have some common themes, of family, connection to their land and culture and spirituality. The stories brim with optimism and uplift and inspire in much the same way that these young people were inspired by the stories of their ancestors.
results.title_for_label: This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project

results.title: What makes me, me
results.creator_credit: Robbie Palm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: One of Robbie Palm’s favourite things is fishing at the creek of his nan’s property. Even though he goes to boarding school in Brisbane, he returns during school holidays to fish. He has been taught by his family the techniques and it is this, and when he plays the Didgeridoo that Robbie feels most connected to his culture. When he plays, he feels proud and watched by his family, both current and past.

results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.

results.title: My family
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: To Malcolm Dotoi, his family includes what he would call his extended family, his cousins and grandfather. They provide support, guidance and inspiration and have helped him to develop into a youth leader. His grandfather, a tribal elder, has taught Malcolm about his connection to the land and to the spiritual world and how all these things have contributed to who Malcolm is today.

results.title: Britain's new resources
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A brief study of the uses to which Britain is putting her limited natural resources; the harvesting, scientific drying, and storing of short grass for feeding cattle all the year round; the planting of forests and cutting of timber; harnessing of hydro-electric power; soap manufacture without fats; the use of seaweed in the manufacture of many products; production of magnesium from the waters of the North Sea.

group_siblings.title: An Hour from London
group_siblings.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Crown Film Unit

results.title: Sense of taste
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Countless guidebooks to the epicurean delights of the Continent have obscured to many, the traditional delicacies of the British table and cellar. This film shows some of the delicacies which have made Britain famous; the haggis, kippers and whisky of Scotland, the York ham, Oxford marmalade and the Stilton cheeses of the towns and cities of provincial England. In London, at the “Cheshire Cheese” tavern in Fleet Street, visitors may partake of the celebrated “Pudding” - made with rump steak, kidneys and oysters and weighing some 60 pounds.

results.title: Old crafts new graces
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Shows that, although the machine dominates the industrial scene of today, traditional British craftsmanship still plays an essential part in the production of certain goods. Examples illustrating such craftsmanship include: the making of a fishing rod; the work of the silversmith; skill with leather in the manufacture of saddles.

results.title: Love of books
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Brief glimpses into the work of British printers and bookmakers. The film shows the reading room of the British Museum; Oliver, the calligraphist and illuminator; Caxton’s first Chaucer; the binding and print in some 18th century volumes; publishers; children’s books and much more.

results.title: An Hour from London
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”
Depicts the great variety of scenery and historical landmarks near to London. By road one can go to East Anglia; by rail to Brighton; by boat to Henley, Oxford, Windsor Castle and Hampton Court. Down the Thames at Greenwich are mementos of Lord Nelson and Samuel Pepys.
